body: Tyrone Garrett has been admitted to the hospital for manic depression more than a dozen times. ''I was in Brooklyn V.A., Manhattan V.A., Northport V.A., Kingsbridge V.A., Maimonides, Kings County, Bellevue, Woodhull,'' he recited. ''Is there any I'm missing?'' Mr. Garrett, 52, first exhibited signs of mania in 1983, while on active duty in the
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; From Mental Health Patient to Wellness Coach

body: MICHAEL SHANNON arrived at Frankies Spuntino in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and avoided the busy back room, preferring to slip into a lone table up front. But at 6 foot 4 with a giant noggin topped off by a brow that could serve as a balcony, he's tough to miss. Add in the fact that he has been nominated for an Academy Award (''Revolutionary
title: THEATER; He Looks Like A Big, Scary Guy Because He Is One

body: IT is rare for fabric makers to get much buzz, let alone credit in fashion bibles like Vogue and Lucky magazines. But Audrey Louise Reynolds, a 27-year-old self-taught designer who lives in Brooklyn, has emerged as the fashion world's artisanal fabric dyer. Her earthy, one-of-a-kind dyes, which she makes in small batches in her backyard in Red
title: A Dyed-and-True Imprint

body: An article last Wednesday about the marketing of Brooklyn's image misstated the location of a rooftop farm that Martha Stewart visited. It is in Greenpoint, not Red Hook. The article also misspelled the surname of the executive editor of Cool Hunting, which created a pop-up store in Manhattan with Brooklyn products. He is Evan Orensten, not
title: CORRECTIONS

body: FLOWERS are blooming in the dead of winter on the fringes of Brooklyn. Inside Lindsey Gamble's bakery, an out-of-the-way, nearly hidden storefront at President and Columbia Streets near the waterfront, butter cream tiers and gum paste orchids climb high. A pile of blue fondant Tiffany boxes seems to tip precariously beside an edible high-heel shoe
title: Brooklyn's Allure? Fancy Cakes, Dahling

body: THERE is still time (through Jan. 9) to catch the 19th annual Holiday Train Show at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. But if you cannot make it, or want to see it later in the year, there's a new picture book titled, appropriately enough, (New York Botanical Garden, $14.95). The lavish color photographs by Robert Benson are accompanied by
title: BOOKSHELF; Twigs and Trains, Illegal Spaces and Chocolate Babka

body: FOR a place selling beer and pulled pork sliders, the Brooklyneer has provoked a lot of controversy. This new bar is dedicated to all things Brooklyn, particularly, the menu declares, the borough's ''newly-emerging food artisans.'' There are Brooklyn hot dogs and Brooklyn pickles and Brooklyn whiskey. You can order toast points spread with Boerum
title: Brooklyn: The Brand

body: FOR a place selling beer and pulled pork sliders, the Brooklyneer has provoked a lot of controversy. This new bar is dedicated to all things Brooklyn, particularly, the menu declares, the borough's ''newly-emerging food artisans.'' body: Tea for Tchaikovsky A holiday tea, featuring nutcracker decorations on the table and goodies like miniature chocolate Yule logs, sandwiches filled with chestnut cream, chocolate-coconut snowballs and ginger scones, will be served in the 35th-floor lobby of the Mandarin Oriental at Columbus Circle through Dec. 26 from 2:30 to 4:30 p.m.; $48 plus any
title: Calendar

body: Carmelo Anthony had finished his workout, and now it was time for reporters to begin theirs. First, a gentle jog down the court to stake out a prime position. Then a series of arm extensions, to make sure the microphones were properly aimed at their target. Then it was time for pleasantries and icebreakers. How are you feeling? ''A little better;
title: Anthony Knows the Drill: Practice, Then Sidestep Queries on the Knicks

author: As told to Abby Ellin.
body: I WAS born in Alabama; my father was a lawyer and a Rhodes scholar. He died when I was a kid, and I never got to fully know him. I resent it to a certain extent. I thought he had a great mind, and it's sad that I never had a chance to explore it. After graduation from Princeton, I joined the Navy and became a navigator on a cargo ship. Toward the
title: THE BOSS; Stage and Screen (and Retail)

author: E-mail: habitats@nytimes.com
body: BEN SCHNEIDER was raised on the Upper West Side, the son of an anthropology professor (his mother, Jane) and a sociology professor (his father, Peter). To the surprise of his bookish parents, his favorite childhood possession was a workbench. ''We had a workbench stashed away in a closet,'' Peter Schneider remembered, ''and when Ben was just a
title: HABITATS; Almost From Scratch, And a Bit of a Mix

body: Send me your own dining questions via dinejournal@nytimes.com or Twitter.com/samsifton. Q. Recently, my wife and I left Manhattan in search of space and quiet and ended up in Fort Greene. It's a great area, with nice restaurants and awesome farmers' and flea markets. But I yearn to find those familiar locations that we adore so in the city, like
title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; Looking for Old Brooklyn? Nosh This Way

body: HAVE you recovered from Thanksgiving indulgence? Good, because the surge of revelry starts in earnest now. Welcome to December, the month of parties. Between now and New Year's Day, even occasional drinkers will find numerous occasions to lift a glass. Some of these drinks will be out of your control. At various compulsory functions, you will be
title: HOLIDAY DRINKS ISSUE; What'll It Be?

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: Cerise Mayo expected better of her bees. She had raised them right, given them all the best opportunities -- acres of urban farmland strewn with fruits and vegetables, a bounty of natural nectar and pollen. Blinded by devotion, she assumed they shared her values: a fidelity to the land, to food sources free of high-fructose corn syrup and
title: BIG CITY; In Mystery (and Culture Clash), Some Brooklyn Bees Turn Red

body: As subjects for musical comedy go, it would be hard to fathom anything less promising than the legal intricacies of the concept of eminent domain. Or, for that matter, the socioeconomic diversity of the crazy quilt of Brooklyn neighborhoods. The great Stephen Sondheim himself might find it tricky work to make lyrical magic of the relationships
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'IN THE FOOTPRINT'; A Brooklyn Civics Lesson, Offered in Word and Song

body: As subjects for musical comedy go, it would be hard to fathom anything less promising than the legal intricacies of the concept of eminent domain. Or, for that matter, the socioeconomic diversity of the crazy quilt of Brooklyn neighborhoods. The great Stephen Sondheim himself might find it tricky work to make lyrical magic of the relationships
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'IN THE FOOTPRINT'; A Brooklyn Civics Lesson, Offered in Word and Song

body: Last week, news emerged of the Bloomberg administration's proposal to extend the No. 7 subway train under the Hudson River to Secaucus, N.J. The idea has become an intriguing Plan B after Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey halted a new commuter rail to Midtown Manhattan because of rising costs. The latest proposal would extend the New York City
title: READER COMMENTS; Extend the 7? Bring It On

body: About two years ago, Debra Salomon was on her way to the new Fairway market in Red Hook, Brooklyn, when she took a wrong turn and found herself on a windblown pier that had two 90-foot Eiffel-like towers rising into the sky for no apparent purpose. Ms. Salomon quickly saw a purpose. She is a designer and teaches design at the City University of New
title: RED HOOK JOURNAL; 2 Idle Towers May Test the Wind's Power to Keep a Bit of Brooklyn Moving

body: MOUNT MORRIS, N.Y. -- For several years, Greg O'Connell moved stealthily, buying building after building along a run-down stretch of Main Street here. It was a puzzling property grab in this rural village, 25 miles south of Rochester, whose commercial district was little more than shabby, vacant storefronts. Few people knew Mr. O'Connell's name,
title: Resurrecting a Village By Buying Up Main Street

body: Is it supposed to snap you to attention or slide you deeper into your buzz? Help you wind down or get you wound up? I've never really understood spiked coffee. In hitching caffeine (a stimulant) to alcohol (a depressant), it strikes me as a curiously self-canceling experience. Like wearing sun block to a tanning parlor. Or eating a Krispy Kreme on
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Spiking Coffee, Opening Eyes

body: When David Black contemplated moving his 21-year-old literary agency to a new office space this summer, he had one nagging worry: the East River. ''Would that be a problem?'' Mr. Black said, pointing to the river from his 27th-floor office window, which boasts sweeping views of the Brooklyn Bridge and the Manhattan skyline. ''Is water a barrier to
title: No Bridge Too Far: Agents Move To Brooklyn

body: ''THERE'S something I want to show you,'' Eli Wallach says, ushering me into his apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. On this occasion what he has in mind is a drawing by Al Hirschfeld, one of two that hang prominently in the front hall: ''That's Annie and me, on our 50th anniversary.'' Anyone with a memory of New York theater -- or, for
title: FILM; Oscar Catches Up With Uncle Eli

body: THE Temple of Dendur is hardly the first place you'd go to see comedians work on their material. But on a Tuesday afternoon in October, Jerry Seinfeld and Colin Quinn were sitting in the Metropolitan Museum of Art near that Egyptian shrine to make a point about transience -- if not of empires, then of jokes. On a break from rehearsing Mr. Quinn's
title: Charting Empires With an Assist From a Comic King

body: David Scharf is planning a little get-together on Sunday in Brooklyn: dinner for 4,500 Hasidic rabbis. ''It's the largest sit-down dinner in New York,'' Mr. Scharf, 58, said Thursday as he surveyed his blank canvas, a cavernous warehouse in Red Hook. The room is a dank, drafty cargo area for cruise ships, part of the Brooklyn Cruise Terminal. The
title: CITY ROOM; When the Dinner Is for 4,500 Rabbis, the Pickle Slicing Starts Early

author: E-mail: peappl@nytimes.com
body: Suffern, N.Y. Tom Sleight remembers the advice his father gave him in case he wanted to take over the family's farm in Dutchess County: Don't do it. It was the 1970s. Family farms were being sold to developers left and right. His family, he said, had been farming in the Hudson Valley since 1640, but his father had concluded that the certainty of
title: OUR TOWNS; Keeping Agriculture Alive Near New York City (Yes, Really)

body: Around Town Museums and Sites American Museum of Natural History Opening on Saturday and running through May 30, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' an annual display of hundreds of free-flying butterflies; timed viewings are every 15 minutes, beginning at 10:15 a.m. Other exhibitions include ''Race to the End of
title: Spare Times

body: French Toast Samples A French toast competition among several Dean & DeLuca cafes will be conducted on Friday at 10 a.m. in the cafe at 620 Eighth Avenue (40th Street). Anyone attending can sample the dishes and vote for their favorites. If the Spirit Moves You An evening devoted to cocktails, spirits and wine will be held on Saturday at the
title: Calendar

author: Susan Silas is a visual artist who lives and works in Brooklyn.
body: TEN years ago I worked briefly as a production accountant on a television show called ''Welcome to New York,'' a sitcom starring Jim Gaffigan as a TV weatherman and Christine Baranski as his city-slicker boss. One episode was about a neighborhood dry cleaner who had magical powers as a matchmaker. The set decorator needed images of couples in love
title: MODERN LOVE; Sex on the Run? No, We Parked

body: Richard Goldstein, an author and historian of the Second World War who has been our guest expert on City Room this week, provided the following second batch of answers to readers' questions. A third and final set of answers about all aspects of New York and the war will be posted on Monday; the first set can be read here. Q.I was born in Brooklyn
title: CITY ROOM; TAKING QUESTIONS | WAR HISTORIAN; On the Home Front, Battleships and Bombs

body: Market Designs on View An exhibition of the designs for a new marketplace for the food vendors in Red Hook, Brooklyn, is on display at the Queens Museum of Art in Flushing Meadow through Sunday from noon to 6 p.m. Wednesdays through Sundays. Admission is by donation. Taco Series Andrew Carmellini of Locanda Verde has turned his talent to Mexico and
title: Calendar

body: Dressed in corduroys, a polo shirt and a windbreaker, the comedian Pat Cooper looked like any other horse player, standing in front of the Off-Track Betting branch on Seventh Avenue at West 38th Street in Manhattan. Instead of the scrappy first-floor area, he headed upstairs to the Winner's Circle area, where entrants pay $5 for a more opulent
title: CITY ROOM; For Comedian, All Bets Are on Aliteration

body: Like many New Yorkers, the people of Brooklyn Heights have something of a love-hate relationship with the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. On the one hand, the highway is the bane of the neighborhood, carrying trucks whose startling rumbles often wake the sleeping, and spewing dust and fumes onto leafy streets named Cranberry, Pineapple and Willow. But
title: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS JOURNAL; As Aging B.Q.E. Faces Reconstruction, Ideas Turn to Tunnels

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Morgan Library & Museum Tuesday at 6:30 p.m., a discussion about Mark Twain's legacy by writers who are also avid readers of his work: the humorist Fran Lebowitz, the novelist Toni Morrison and the New York Times columnist Frank Rich; $30, $25 for members. The discussion is in conjunction with the exhibition ''Mark
title: Spare Times

body: STROLLING a street fair should be a wholesome, cheerful endeavor, a chance to ogle artisanal wares, help a giggling toddler onto a pony or watch your buttoned-down neighbor slam power chords with his garage band. But New York's traffic-thwarting, tube-sock-peddling version -- the kind that plagues Midtown Manhattan avenues in the summer -- inspires
title: Brooklyn Sounds, Brews and Chow: A Mile-Long Street Fair With Moxie

body: In the 1940s, when E. B. White, the author and columnist for The New Yorker, looked out of his back windows onto the private Turtle Bay Gardens along East 48th Street in Manhattan, an old but picturesque willow tree commanded his view. He draped the tree in metaphor and imbued it with immortality by writing about it in the concluding lines of his
title: CITY ROOM; For E. B. White's Willow Tree, Chapter Ends

body: Caroline Giuliani is most likely headed the way of Boy George and Naomi Campbell: donning gloves, a pale face mask, neon vest and work boots before commencing several hours of scrubbing, sweeping and tidying the messy corners of a Sanitation Department garage in Manhattan. Such is the fate for many who are assigned court-ordered community service,
title: In Community Service, Celebrity Justice Means The Same Dirty Work

body: Elizabeth Millien, 27, a trained opera singer who is the daughter of a caterer and a musician, is supporting her dreams of stardom in New York the old-fashioned way: by working in the food business. After touring Europe and South America with the Harlem Gospel Choir, she began working four months ago as a greeter -- officially, customer relations
title: ENTRY LEVEL; Customer Help, in a Voice That Saves Her Voice

body: WHEN Stumptown Coffee Roasters opens its coffee bar in Red Hook, Brooklyn, early next month, it will be missing something that people have come to expect of such establishments: espresso. There will be only coffee brewed by the cup. The selection, depending on the season, could be staggering. You will be able to drink from the full range of beans
title: Stumptown Focuses on the Brew

body: AT times, the large back room at Café Grumpy in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, has so many customers typing and wearing noise-canceling headphones that it looks like an office without the cubicles. A second Café Grumpy location, in Chelsea, prohibited laptops after too many customers ran extension cords across the room. The ban still rankles with some in
title: Coffee Bars: Unplug, Drink, Go

body: It's a good thing that I hadn't realized how much money FreshDirect was losing in recent years, because it probably would have given me a heart attack for fear that the online grocer would go out of business. Last week, the gang at You're the Boss, the Times blog on small business, told the story in the paper and online of how FreshDirect was
title: BUCKS; Sizing Up FreshDirect

body: On a muggy evening this month, Erik Frampton made his way to the Brooklyn waterfront to sit aboard a retired oil tanker and listen to a salty, gay sailor read from his memoir. It was 8 p.m. in Red Hook, and though the reading was supposed to have already started, no one else had arrived. Mr. Frampton, 36, a laid-back pianist, settled into a hammock
title: RED HOOK JOURNAL; A Retired Tanker, a Home And a Summertime Stage

body: I HAD the route mapped out in my mind. I would bike from the Lower East Side of Manhattan, hit the taco trucks along the ball fields of Red Hook, Brooklyn, cruise through Prospect Park over to Brighton Beach for a quick dip, then hypotenuse it back to a bar in Williamsburg to watch the World Cup finals. Out of curiosity, I consulted Google Maps's
title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; Google Leads, You Pedal

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: Up the Harlem River, past the saltwater marshes of Swindler Cove, beyond the Sherman Creek Nature Trail and the quaint gingerbread boathouse, the bucolic landscape gives way to a sinister hive, where the higher machine species are breeding for their eventual takeover of the earth. That's how it looks, anyway, as you glide past the dense stack of
title: CITY CRITIC; A Singular Perspective On the Urban Mosaic

body: BAMBOO is one of the world's fastest-growing plants, adding as much as three feet in a single day. That growth rate, along with the giant grass's sturdy hollow stalks (with a strength-to-weight ratio similar to that of steel) may explain why bamboo is being heralded by bikers, environmentalists and social entrepreneurs as a material with no carbon
title: NOTICED; Just Don't Let a Panda Borrow Your Bicycle

body: Click on Gallery to Enlarge A homeless man in an ''I NY'' shirt asleep on a bench in Staten Island. A just-married couple, cuddling on a bench in Brooklyn Ferry Park. A crowd doing yoga on the beach in the Rockaways, another crowd doing pilates by the East River, a third snapping pictures of the Brooklyn Bridge at sundown. Swimmers, slackers,
title: CITY ROOM; The Waterfront, Covered

body: 'WE THE PEOPLE: AMERICA ROCKS!' A great performer, it's often said, can recite the phone book and be riveting. Theatreworks USA has based its new musical on a document that's far more fascinating, yet one that children may consider just as dull and daunting: the United States Constitution. But if every civics lesson were as funny, fresh and
title: SPARE TIMES; For Children

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Alice Austen House Outdoor events: On Friday, ''Rock the House,'' music with a D.J. beginning at 7 p.m. and live bands from 8 to 10 p.m. On Saturday at 6:30 p.m., a dance program built around the themes of nature and the life of Isadora Duncan, presented by the Isadora Duncan Dance Company, the youth dance ensemble
title: SPARE TIMES

body: THE first time I bought flowers for myself was about five years ago at the Greenmarket in Union Square, in the midst of the hottest, dullest days of summer. Feeling very alone that afternoon for a reason now forgotten, I stood admiring some tulips. For $8 they could be mine. I was in my mid-20s and it seemed like such a luxury to buy myself flowers
title: What to Do With a Blossom

body: If print is dead, the people who planned these events sure don't know it. On Friday the bookstore Freebird Books in Red Hook, Brooklyn, presents an evening of punk reminiscences, a fund-raiser for Books Through Bars, an organization that provides prisoners with books. Mike Edison, drummer for the Raunch Hands, hosts a talk with Eric Davidson,
title: Weekend Miser

body: BLUFFTON, S.C. -- This month Palmetto Bluff, a high-end resort community near Hilton Head, S.C., will break ground on an organic garden. In this age of eating local food and sustainable growing, the concept is hardly novel. What makes Palmetto Bluff's garden different is its ambitions. When completed it will be part of a 100-acre farm with crops
title: SQUARE FEET; A Vision Challenges the Planned Community Stereotype in South Carolina

body: Medieval Meals Food and cooking in the Middle Ages will be the subject of a free hourlong tour for children ages 4 and older and adults at the Cloisters of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park on Aug. 1 at 1 p.m. Museum admission is required but reservations are not. Information: metmuseum.org. Sips and Nibbles A free tasting of
title: Calendar

author: E-mail: habitats@nytimes.com
body: DECADES before Carrie Bradshaw settled into her apartment in an East Side brownstone, the neighborhood was a mecca for young single women seeking a taste of the big city. And among the legions drawn to the area was a 21-year-old design school graduatenamed Robbin Brosterman, who in 1980 moved to a one-bedroom apartment on East 57th Street. ''A
title: HABITATS | LENOX HILL; The Studio, Act II: Enter Husband

body: With our views blocked by concrete and metal, it is easy to forget that New York is surrounded by water. That's why on Saturday, the third annual City of Water Day Festival will let the masses ferry, paddle, row, canoe and kayak their way to the city's waterfronts for a full day of free activities sponsored by the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance
title: WEEKEND MISER; City of Water Day Festival

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Louis Armstrong House Museum Saturday at 1 p.m., a free outdoor performance of Dixieland, early jazz and spirituals by the group the Recessionals. The museum is open Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Louis Armstrong House Museum, 34-56 107th Street, Corona, Queens ,
title: Spare Times

body: A SUMMER share in the five boroughs? A gay-themed circus? A subway to the next Jersey Shore? Forget about the Jitney. Summer offers plenty of reasons to stay in New York. Here are 10 new hot spots to drink, party, play and chill in the city. FOOD AND DRINK 1. Rooftop Bar With rooftop bars popping up across the city skyline with dizzying frequency
title: 10 New Hot Spots If Summer Needs Sizzle

body: BENEATH a floating dock off Governors Island, tucked behind the squat octagonal white ventilation tower for the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, there are oysters growing in New York Harbor. And not just any oysters. These little bivalves, 500,000 strong, make up the largest concentrated oyster population that the harbor has seen in perhaps a century. On a
title: Nurturing New York's Oysters

body: To get to the city pool in Brooklyn's Gowanus neighborhood in the 1970s, a swimmer ran a gantlet. The pool sat amid factories and workshops, the streets around it crowded with trucks. Sex workers met clients near the gates, on Douglass Street. Still, clutching towels, local residents in need of a dip knew where to go, a block from the noxious
title: CITY ROOM; A Reprieve For an Oasis In Brooklyn With an Edge

body: Mr. Chera, 67, is a founder of Crown Acquisitions, which has an ownership interest in dozens of retail and office properties throughout North America, including trophy buildings in Manhattan like the Fred F. French Building at 551 Fifth Avenue and the retail space at 666 Fifth and the St. Regis Hotel. Q How's business? A Great. Q Better than last
title: SQUARE FEET | THE 30-MINUTE INTERVIEW; Stanley Chera

body: 'DANCING IN THE SKY' Forget about all the world's being a stage -- some parts are much more theatrical than others. And few outdoor spaces in New York appear more suited to everyday human dramas than the High Line, the elevated railway-turned-park on the West Side of Manhattan. ''It feels like a stage for the whole city, and kids can really get
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: On Tuesday evening, at just past 6, a few dozen people - tugboat captains, towing company owners, a maritime journalist or two - gathered on the rusting deck of the Mary A. Whalen, a retired oil tanker tied up in a berth at Pier 9B in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The sun was going down over Governors Island, and a bagpiper, in traditional cap and kilt, was
title: CITY ROOM; To Chronicler Of All Things Maritime, A Farewell

body: Pop Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. Sam Amidon (Wednesday) A banjoist and singer from Brattleboro, Vt., Mr. Amidon plays earnest folk songs (often based on traditional material) that are filled with little surprises, like a sudden, off-key warble or a bit of sharp percussion. With Partyface. At 6:30 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217
title: The Listings

body: For Children 'Amazon Voyage: Vicious Fishes & Other Riches' (Friday through Thursday) The anaconda isn't real, but the piranhas are. In this simulated trip down the Amazon, a new exhibition at the New York Hall of Science, children can learn about the creatures of the river, their adaptations and their life cycles. The exhibits include live
title: SPARE TIMES

body: NEWPORT, R.I. -- The Cliff Walk, a promenade that winds more than three miles along this city's rugged coast, is not for the vertigo-prone. It looms high over the crashing surf, drawing a constant stream of visitors who peer over the stunning precipice as they stroll. Some wince and step back. Others dare to clamber down dirt paths that run from
title: NEWPORT JOURNAL; Seeking to Balance Beauty and Safety On the Cliff Walk

body: The new ''Food Lovers' Guide to Brooklyn'' by Sherri Eisenberg (Globe Pequot Press, $14.95) is reasonably up-to-date for a borough where new food places open their doors by the minute. Its 328 pages are packed, district by district, with detailed listings, maps and descriptions. Some of the neighborhood groupings segue from one into another, like
title: FOOD STUFF; A Borough's Treats, Now in a Book

body: Around Town Museums and Sites BARTOW-PELL MANSION MUSEUM Monday, 3:30 to 5 p.m., ''Red, White, and Blue -- With You!,'' a Flag Day celebration with a discussion and a flag-making workshop. $5 per person, $3 for members. Registration required: (718) 885-1461 or e-mail info@bpmm.org. 895 Shore Road North, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx ,
title: Spare Times: Around Town

body: CENTENNIAL BEE-DAY PARTY In Kafka's ''Metamorphosis'' Gregor Samsa awakens to discover that he has become an enormous cockroach. While that may be among the most unwelcome transformations on record, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will offer one on Saturday that's shorter, sweeter and sunnier: children changing themselves into bees. The process is part
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Pop Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. BLITZEN TRAPPER (Wednesday) A folk-rock sextet with an avant-garde bent, this band from Portland, Ore., is often -- and accurately -- compared to Pavement (both bands are charmingly scrappy), but its shimmering songs are also heavily indebted to Paul McCartney (although really, what isn't?).
title: The Listings

body: BLOOMSDAY may not have reached the nerd heights of Comic-Con, but it's still a glorious expression of fandom. Each year, in honor of the raunchy, transcendent Dublin day recounted in James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' -- which details the comings and goings of Leopold Bloom on June 16, 1904 -- acolytes rejoice with readings, parties and pub crawls. Few
title: Stream of Conviviality For Leopold Bloom's Day

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: From water's edge you can cross the Hudson River -- or the East River, as you prefer -- in less time than it often takes to wait for the subway. Even at the height of rush hour, you'll get a seat, quite likely one near a window. From out on the water, the city you think you know will seem taller, more glamorous, more cinematic. You may pass under a
title: CITY CRITIC; What New York Needs: More Water Taxis

body: 'TIGERS THE EXHIBITION' The most common way of getting inside a tiger isn't much fun -- just ask the deer in Asia. But now children in New York can inhabit a Bengal tiger through means that are risk free and entertaining, allowing them not only to see the creature's bones and muscles but also to perceive the world through its senses. That
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Tuesday at 6:30 p.m., ''Adventures in the Global Kitchen: Polar Cocktails,'' a discussion, with sampling, of the cocktails that were popular a century ago, with David Wondrich, an author and drink connoisseur, and Don Lee, a mixologist at Momofuku Ssäm Bar; $25. On view through Jan.
title: Spare Times

body: Following are some markets around New York City selling products made by local food artisans. GREENPOINT FOOD MARKET Church of the Messiah, 129 Russell Street (Nassau Avenue), Greenpoint, Brooklyn; greenpointfoodmarket.wordpress.com. One Saturday a month, noon to 5 p.m. (the next market is June 26). Worth tasting: P&H sodas, Masala Loca Indian
title: New Yorkers Reinvent the Pushcart

body: THEY carry home-grown radishes and red-cooked pork. They transport dozens of empanadas, juggling sheet pans on the G train. They pack boxes of butterscotch cupcakes, Sichuan-spiced beef jerky and grapefruit marmalade. They haul boiled peanuts, ice-grinding machines, sandwich presses and at least one toaster oven painted hot pink. One Saturday
title: Their Future, Made by Hand

body: Two days after a 16-year-old Brooklyn girl was chased down and fatally shot on a street near her home, investigators have arrested an 18-year-old man in the killing, the police said on Saturday. The suspect, Kendale Robinson, approached the victim, Al-Taya Conyers, in Boerum Hill about 11:45 p.m. on Wednesday and shot her with a .40-caliber pistol,
title: Man Arrested in Killing Of Brooklyn Teenager

body: POP Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. ELLEN ALLIEN (Saturday) A Berlin D.J. and producer and a founder of the label BPitch Control, Ms. Allien creates electronic compositions that are lingering, ghostly affairs, especially well suited to small spaces. With J D H and Dave P. At 10 p.m., Santos Party House, 96 Lafayette Street,
title: The Listing

body: Sure, it's an expensive city, but it doesn't have to be. Every week we'll offer a select look at interesting ways to spend the weekend without spending a lot. Learn to parry with the instructors of the Manhattan Fencing Center. Some were members of the United States Olympic fencing team in Beijing, but they will teach foes of all ages and skill
title: WEEKEND MISER; Free Fencing Lessons, Yoga and Ballet

body: One spring day in 1976, a bedraggled pigeon traipsed through the open doorway of the Koho School of Sumi-E, a tiny, cramped Japanese brush painting school in SoHo. The bird couldn't fly. The school's owner and sole teacher, Koho Yamamoto (students call her Sensei), fed it rice and posted a sign in her storefront window that asked, ''Is anyone
title: CITY ROOM; An Endangered Japanese Art Form Loses Its Outpost in SoHo

body: ROSENDALE, N.Y. -- Until about a year ago, Fredrick Arnold was living the life of a Williamsburg hipster. An aspiring filmmaker with mutton-chop sideburns, he spent his working hours waiting tables at Dumont Burger, and his off hours on projects like an animated music video for one of his favorite bands, Casper & the Cookies. But after being laid
title: 90 Miles Upstate, A Brooklyn Feel

body: JOHN AMEROSO didn't hoe the rows of vegetables that help feed the Bronx at the Padre Plaza Success Garden in the borough's Mott Haven section. He didn't pick any tomatoes from the vines at the Brooklyn Rescue Mission's farm. And he didn't turn the composting bins that kept East New York Farms! fertile ground for collards, cilantro and chard. But
title: An Urban Farming Pioneer Sows His Own Legacy

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM Sunday at 5:30 p.m., ''Sing It With Flowers: A 19th-Century Serenade to Mother,'' featuring members of the Bond Street Euterpean Singing Society; reservations required: (212) 777-1089. 29 East Fourth Street, East Village , merchantshouse.org; $25, $10 for members.20100506 MOUNT VERNON HOTEL
title: Spare Times

body: For its 25th season SummerStage is expanding beyond Central Park into parks throughout New York City. In Central Park, where SummerStage began in 1986, the season of free performances opens on June 1 with the New York Pops and Melody Gardot. It continues through September with highlights including the African singer Baaba Maal (June 14), Meshell
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; SummerStage Lineup

body: First the man, with a ponytail and fraying green pants, started picking up the trash. Then he planted a purple plum tree and a garden with hydrangeas. By the time he put up a sign in Coffey Park requesting banana peels, the neighborhood was paying attention. ''All the Spanish ladies walking through here started talking to me,'' recalled the man,
title: For Gardener, Love of a Park Comes With the Job

body: The Local Stop feature last Sunday, about Red Hook, Brooklyn, misstated the address of the Waterfront Museum. It is at 290 Conover Street, on Pier 44 -- not at 699 Columbia Street. An accompanying map also included the error.
title: Corrections

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK Saturday at 1 p.m., ''Portals to the Past: Archaeology at New York City's Historic Houses,'' a discussion about historic buildings in all five boroughs, including tenements, estates and storefronts; co-sponsored by the Professional Archaeologists of New York City. Tuesday at 6:30 p.m.,
title: Spare Times

body: Luis Malagon felt blessed when he, his wife and their daughter were offered $11,000 a month to work at a new religious social service agency being planned in Brooklyn. He quit his job as a building inspector in South Carolina in February, put his house up for sale and borrowed money to move to Sunset Park. Settling into a cramped apartment, they
title: Brooklyn Pastor's Job Offers: From Blessing to Curse

body: The Brooklyn neighborhood of Red Hook may be most famous these days for affordable Swedish design, but a group of artists is giving the once rough-and-tumble peninsula a softer, more creative edge. Their fondness for turning salvaged objects into objets d'art makes the area feel like ''a small town of misfit toys,'' in one resident's words, which
title: LOCAL STOP | RED HOOK; Past a Blue and Yellow Box, Lots of Art

body: Each week on the City Room blog, editors select a New Yorker to answer readers' questions. title: TAKING QUESTIONS FUN FOR CHILDREN; Family Getaways Off the Beaten Paths

body: A GREAT cup of coffee is enough to make any place a neighborhood favorite. And if that place also serves good food, with a couple of standouts, it could become a local institution. Here are three possibilities for finding a satisfying bite to eat, with some of the best coffee in the city. Iris Cafe, 20 Columbia Place (Joralemon Street), Brooklyn
title: $25 AND UNDER; Three That Come With Coffee

body: To hear it described by one broker, the football-field-long former Navy warehouse off the Brooklyn waterfront inspired awe from all but a few of the prospective buyers invited on a tour of the long-vacant site last month. But that awe, said the broker, Chris Havens, the chief executive of Creative Real Estate Group in Brooklyn, quickly dissolved
title: SQUARE FEET; An Empty Warehouse Holds Dreams of Industrial Jobs

body: In December, the pastor of a fledgling storefront church in Red Hook, Brooklyn, began spreading word among several dozen evangelical Christian congregations that he was hiring employees for a huge new social service program. Hundreds of applicants packed meetings where, many people say, the pastor declared that he had a grant from World Vision, the
title: Church Hires Hundreds, but Doubts Surround Project

body: CENTRAL PARK provides a haven for migratory warblers and American elms. It is a less congenial habitat for those humans who require a diet more varied and interesting than stiff pretzels and tepid hot dogs. But there is hope for this beleaguered species, in the form of Connecticut-style lobster rolls, artisanal sausages and freshly fired pizza.
title: Central Park Snacks Via Brooklyn Flea

body: IN the magazine world, there has traditionally been no more glamorous place to work than Condé Nast. Brandon Holley can attest to that. When she was the editor in chief of Jane, Condé Nast's monthly for young single women, she had a big office in the company's Times Square headquarters, a driver and a lavish expense account. She sat in the front
title: The Beat Goes Online, Minus the Glitz

body: For more than 30 years now, sharp-eyed New Yorkers have been finding them on ledges, windowsills and store counters -- poker-chip-size coins that reveal themselves to be something far more mysterious than loose change. The inch-wide ceramic discs, painted in iridescent colors, have the rough, weathered feel of ancient treasure. Each is embossed
title: Statements By an Artist, For the Palms Of Strangers

author: Andrew Cotto lives in Carroll Gardens and teaches composition, over the racket of jackhammers, at the ASA Institute in Downtown Brooklyn. Join a reader discussion of his rant at nytimes.com/cityroom.
body: WE left Manhattan for Brooklyn in 1997. Even then, before it was the rage, it felt like a destination. We kept track of all the things the neighborhoods of Brooklyn had over the metropolis of Manhattan: actual diversity, affordable restaurants, more parking and less pretension. But the best thing, no doubt, every time, was the sky. Brooklyn had
title: COMPLAINT BOX BROOKLYN RISING; They're Stealing My Sky

body: The Environmental Protection Agency designated the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn a Superfund site on Tuesday and announced plans to clean up more than a century's worth of noxious pollutants there. The decision ended a contentious debate and was a blow to the Bloomberg administration, which had proposed a cleanup without such a designation. The city
title: E.P.A. Readies Cleanup Plan For Gowanus

body: IN the nine years since he came to New York with $500 in his pocket, Martin-Christopher Harper estimates that he has moved at least 40 times. When he lists the neighborhoods he has lived in -- in chronological order -- he sounds like a bartender reciting a long list of microbrews: ''Brooklyn, Chelsea Hotel for a moment, Bronx, Carroll Gardens,
title: Boxed In

author: Email: habitats@nytimes.com
body: BACK in the 1970s, a staple of starter apartments in New York was a poster advertising rye bread, an image that featured a member of a distinctly non-Jewish ethnic group with the tagline, ''You don't have to be Jewish to love Levy's. ...'' But if there's any place where the poster is an appropriate item of décor, it's the West Village apartment of
title: HABITATS | WEST VILLAGE; Her Second Home, the One Without Wheels

body: They honor stickball tournaments and dance teachers, doughnut-store openings or New Yorkers reaching the century mark. They spread good will, honor bravery and service, and cement political alliances. Every year, writing in formal prose with 14th-century flourishes, the presidents of the five boroughs distribute hundreds of proclamations and
title: With the Stroke of a Pen, Honoring the Little Known, if Only for a Day

body: More than a half-dozen gentrified neighborhoods in Brooklyn would lose subsidized day care centers for low-income families under proposed city budget cuts, Bloomberg administration officials said Wednesday. A list of the 15 day care centers that are scheduled to close in July, 10 of them in Brooklyn, was released by the Administration for
title: City Seeks to Close 15 Day Care Centers, Most in Brooklyn, in Budget Cut

body: What's extraordinary about Gregory Mosher's beautifully observed production of ''A View From the Bridge'' is how ordinary most of it feels. Very little in this revival of Arthur Miller's kitchen-sink drama with knives, which opened Sunday night at the Cort Theater, calls loudly for our consideration. Voices are often kept to a just audible murmur,
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'A VIEW FROM THE BRIDGE'; A View From Brooklyn Of Tragedy Most Classic

body: There were the quizzical looks, the dirty looks, the snide remarks and far worse when Ruth McBride Jordan walked down the street with a gaggle of her children in tow. Her son James, one of a dozen children from her two marriages, was often embarrassed, sometimes scared. Sometimes they had to endure the most despicable racial epithet. His mother,
title: Ruth McBride Jordan, 88, a Son's Heroine

body: Andrea Arden, 41, trains dogs for Animal Planet's canine rags-to-riches makeover series, ''Underdog to Wonderdog,'' and for 15 years has run her own dog education/behavior modification business from three locations in Manhattan, including Animal Haven, a shelter on Centre Street. Separated from her husband, she lives in Red Hook, Brooklyn, with two
title: SUNDAY ROUTINE | ANDREA ARDEN; The Movie's Coming On. No Barking.

body: There were the quizzical looks, the dirty looks, the snide remarks and far worse when Ruth McBride Jordan walked down the street with a gaggle of her kids in tow. Her son James, one of a dozen children from her two marriages, was often embarrassed, sometimes scared. ''Look at her with those little niggers!'' he sometimes heard. His mother, who was
title: Ruth McBride Jordan, Subject of Son's Book 'Color of Water,' Dies at 88

body: Tiny, sweet Maine shrimp have a short season, a mere six weeks in winter. But the current harvest is so robust, the state Department of Marine Resources has extended it to May 1. That's good news for connoisseurs of this treat, especially since a fleet of Maine fishermen, the Port Clyde Fresh Catch, has organized a Community Supported Fisheries
title: FOOD STUFF; The Season for Maine Shrimp Is Extended

body: IN 1947, while doing research for a screenplay in the Red Hook neighborhood of Brooklyn, Arthur Miller heard a story that reminded him of the plot of a Greek tragedy. An Italian-American longshoreman had turned in to authorities two illegal immigrants, relatives he had been sheltering in his home, in order to stop one of them from marrying his
title: Death of a Friendship, Birth of a Play

body: URBAN renewal. The phrase conjures up government-backed megaprojects from the '70s, but it's organic to New York, where someone is always getting off the bus, train or plane. In the last year, the city has opened a hot new park, Lincoln Center celebrated its 50th anniversary with a major face-lift that includes a new fountain with 353 custom-made,
title: 36 Hours: New York City

body: Some quarrels never seem to fade away, and the anti-Communist battles of the 1940s and 1950s are being fought long after most of the original antagonists are dead. Not only do the arguments over Alger Hiss and the Rosenbergs live on, but the question of whether Elia Kazan and Budd Schulberg made the classic 1954 film ''On the Waterfront'' to
title: A New Look at an Old Quarrel Over 'On the Waterfront'
